docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 2 Possession of land, equity and other proceedings [ss 133–139]

heading.title: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
Subdivision 2 Possession of land, equity and other proceedings [ss 133–139]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
Subdivision 2 Possession of land, equity and other proceedings [ss 133–139]

leg:heading.title: Possession of land, equity and other proceedings [ss 133–139]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 133] s 133 Jurisdiction in proceedings for possession of land

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction in proceedings for possession of land

p.text: The Court shall have the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court, and may exercise all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court, in proceedings for possession of land the value of which does not exceed $20,000, as determined by the Court.
[subs (1) am Act 169 of 1989 sÂ 3 and Sch 3]
Nothing in subsection (1) applies in respect of proceedings under the Landlord and Tenant Act, 1899 .

Because of the limitation on the value of the land this section is rarely invoked. Part III of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1899, which conferred certain jurisdiction on the District Court, was repealed by the District Court Act (see s 181 and 2nd Sch). Actions for ejectment were replaced by proceedings for possession. Section 92 CPA provides for judgment for possession of land.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 134] s 134 Jurisdiction in equity proceedings

p.text: The Court shall have the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court, and may exercise all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court, in proceedings for:

the foreclosure or redemption of a mortgage or the enforcing of any charge or lien where the amount owing in respect of the mortgage, charge or lien does not exceed $20,000, as determined by the Court,
the specific performance, rectification, delivery up or cancellation of any agreement for:
the sale or purchase of any property at a price not exceeding $20,000, or
the lease of any property the value of which does not exceed $20,000, as determined by the Court,

an order under section 3 of the Testator's Family Maintenance and Guardianship of Infants Act, 1916 (as in force immediately before that Act was amended by the Succession Amendment (Intestacy) Act 2009), or a family provision order under Chapter 3 of the Succession Act 2006,
relief against fraud or mistake where the damage sustained or the estate or fund in respect of which relief is sought does not exceed $20,000 in amount or value as determined by the Court,

the execution of a trust or a declaration that a trust subsists, where the estate or fund subject or alleged to be subject to the trust does not exceed $20,000 in amount or value, as determined by the Court, or
the administration of the estate of a deceased person, where the estate does not exceed $20,000 in amount or value, as determined by the Court, or
any application under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 , or

any equitable claim or demand for recovery of money or damages, whether liquidated or unliquidated (not being a claim or demand of a kind to which any other paragraph of this subsection applies), in an amount not exceeding the Court's jurisdictional limit.

[subs (1) am Act 170 of 1984 sÂ 5 and Sch 8 ; Act 169 of 1989 sÂ 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 58 of 1997 Sch 1 ; Act 4 of 1999 Sch 2 ; Act 28 of 2005 Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005 ; Act 75 of 2008 s 4 and Sch 2.2[1], effective 1 March 2009 ; Act 29 of 2009 Sch 2.3, effective 1 March 2010]

In any proceedings pursuant to subsection (1)(c) , the Court shall not have power to make an order for provision under the Testator's Family Maintenance and Guardianship of Infants Act, 1916 (as in force immediately before that Act was amended by the Succession Amendment (Intestacy) Act 2009), or Chapter 3 of the Succession Act 2006, that will or may result in the amount of provision so made exceeding $250,000.

[subs (2) am Act 170 of 1984 sÂ 5 and Sch 8 ; am Act 169 of 1989 sÂ 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 58 of 1997 sÂ 3 and SchÂ 1; Act 75 of 2008 s 4 and Sch 2.2[2], effective 1 March 2009 ; Act 29 of 2009 Sch 2.3, effective 1 March 2010]

In any proceedings pursuant to subsection (1)(g), the Court has no power to make an order for financial adjustment under Part 3 of the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 that will or may result in the amount of the adjustment so made exceeding $250,000.
[subs (3) insrt Act 58 of 1997 sÂ 3 and Sch 1 ; am Act 4 of 1999 Sch 2]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(a)–(b), (b), (d)–(f), (f), sÂ 134(1)(h), sÂ 137, sÂ 4, sÂ 44, sÂ 46.
In practice the jurisdiction given by sÂ 134(1)(a)–(b) , (d)–(f) is rarely used mainly because of the relatively small monetary limits on jurisdiction.

The other power to grant such relief is contained in sÂ 46 . However the jurisdiction conferred by that section is ancillary to the exercise of the jurisdiction of the court to hear and dispose of the actions specified in sÂ 44 : Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072Â ; see also Nelson v Fernwood Fitness Centre Pty Ltd [1999] FCA 802; BC9903266Â .

The monetary limit in sÂ 134(1)(h) is the same monetary limit as applies to actions in the court for damages: see DCA sÂ 4 . The monetary limit for claims falling withins sÂ 134(1)(a) – (b) , (d) – (f) is limited to $20,000. The words in parentheses exclude from the conferral of jurisdiction in para (h) claims or demands of kinds to which any other paragraph applies: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Hadfield (2001) 53 NSWLR 614; [2001] NSWCA 440; BC200107866 at [51]–[53], [68]–[69]Â . When exercising jurisdiction under this section the court has all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court: see also DCA sÂ 137 .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 133, subs (1)(a).

An action brought by a mortgagee to recover possession of the land is covered by sÂ 133 nor subs (1)(a) of this section and the court will have jurisdiction to hear the action if the value of the land is under $20,000: RÂ vÂ Judge Willes; Ex parte Abbey National Building Society [1954] 1Â WLR 136; RÂ vÂ Judge Dutton Briant; Ex parte Abbey National Building Society [1957] 2Â QB 497; [1957] 2Â All ER 625. The court has jurisdiction even though the right to redemption is disputed: Powell vÂ Roberts (1869) LR 9Â Eq 169. Whether the court has jurisdiction in respect of the amount depends on the amount of the charge at the time the action is brought: Shields, Whitley and District Amalgamated Model Building Society vÂ Richards (1901) 84 LT 587.

Proceedings may be entertained by the District Court under sÂ 134(1)(a) even though the mortgagor or person giving the charge or lien is bankrupt: Medhurst vÂ Golden (1867) 16 LT 50. If questions involving considerable difficulty are involved, although the court has jurisdiction in respect of amount, it may decline to exercise its jurisdiction: Murphy vÂ Mitchell (1879) 5Â VLR (E) 194 at 199; see also Mayor of Essendon vÂ Moore (1899) 20 ALT 198.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 134.15] (b) Relief regarding sale and lease agreements

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 Subsection (1)(b).

heading.title: (b) Relief regarding sale and lease agreements

p.text: Subsection (1)(b) deals with any agreement for sale purchase or lease of any property. A counterclaim for specific performance of an agreement for the sale of land worth more than $20,000 can be dealt with only so far as it affords a defence to the claim: Beech v Martin (1886) 12 VLR 571Â . The words “the value of the property” mean the value of the fee simple and accordingly in the case of a lease of property proceeding $20,000 in value, the court does not have jurisdiction although the value of the actual interest granted by the lease is less than that amount: Angel v Jay [1911] 1Â KB 666; De Vries v Smallbridge [1928] 1Â KB 482. However in the case of a sale or purchase the criterion is the amount of the purchase money and the court has jurisdiction where purchase money does not exceed $20,000 although the value of the property exceeds that sum: RÂ v Judge Whitehorne [1904] 1Â KB 827.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 134.20] (c) Family provision and TFM claims

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 134(1)(c).
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 Ch 3, s 59, ss 78–85, sÂ 91.

Section 134(1)(c) is to be construed not restrictively, but rather giving full effect to its terms. The District Court when exercising jurisdiction conferred on it by subs(1)(c) to make an order under Succession Act 2006 s 59 , may make an order out of notional estate and has power to make orders designating property as notional estate under any of the notional estate provisions of Succession Act 2006 ss 78–85 : Birch v O’Connor [2005] NSWCA 90 [12]–[20]Â (decided based on Family Provision Act 1982, now replaced by Succession Act 2006 Ch 3 ). If the family provision proceedings are otherwise within the court’s jurisdiction, the District Court may grant probate (under sÂ 91 of the Succession Act 2006) for the purpose of allowing the proceedings to be determined: Estate of Terry [2012] NSWSC 927; BC201206351Â per WhiteÂ J at [12].
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(d).
Under sÂ 134(1)(d) the court may set aside a deed obtained by fraud releasing a judgment debt and costs: Stephenson v Garnett [1898] 1Â QB 677.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(e).

The court has jurisdiction under sÂ 134(1)(e) in cases of constructive trusts: Clayton v Renton (1867) LR 4Â Eq 158. If the defendant is alleged to hold a tenancy in trust for the plaintiff, the value of the estate is the value of the tenancy and not the freehold value of the property: McDonald v Barnes (1951) 101 LJo 667, distinguishing Angel v Jay [1911] 1Â KB 666.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(f).

A person interested in the estate of a deceased person is not entitled as of right to an administration order: Pearson v Pearson (1886) 56 LT 445. A statement of claim under sÂ 134(1)(f) need not contain an averment that the value of the estate to be administered does not exceed $20,000, and the onus is on the defendant to show the value is not within jurisdiction: Cheesewright v Thorn (1869) 38 LJ Ch 615; Shepherd v Patent Composition Pavement Co (1874) 5Â AJR 27; Martin v Keane (1878) 4Â VLR (E) 115. The court under this provision has jurisdiction to entertain an equitable, as distinct from a legal, claim: Dobell v Parker [1960] NSWR 188; (1960) 61 SR (NSW) 51 at 64–5Â per Hardie J. The court has an absolute discretion over the costs of an administration action and may order the plaintiff to pay them: Plumb v Craker (1885) 16 QBD 40Â .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(g).
(NSW) Property (Relationships) Act 1984.

The District Court has jurisdiction pursuant to sÂ 134(1)(g) and sÂ 8 Property (Relationships) Act 1984 to make declarations in relation to parties’ existing beneficial interests in property — irrespective of the value of those interests: Bourdon v Outridge [2006] NSWSC 491; BC200604067 at [20]Â per WhiteÂ J, 22Â May 2006. The court's jurisdiction to make orders for financial adjustment under the Act is limited to an order that will or may result in an adjustment not exceeding $250,000: District Court Act 1973 s 134(1)(g) and (3): Bourdon v Outridge [2006] NSWSC 491; BC200604067 at [25]Â per WhiteÂ J, 22 May 2006. Further, only the Supreme Court has jurisdiction in relation to the declaration of the constructive trust. However, in relation to such claims brought in the Supreme Court, it might be appropriate to consider if there are any cost consequences of the constructive trust litigation having resulted in the plaintiff receiving no more than entitled to receive under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 : Deves v Porter [2003] NSWSC 625; BC200304411 at [70]Â per CampbellÂ J.
As to the limits of the power conferred by s 134(1)(h) see Ciccarelli v Cavasinni Developments [2004] NSWSC 788; BC200405706 at [84]Â and following.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 134(1)(h).

It must be remembered there is a difference between equitable claims in the District Court and equitable defences. The jurisdiction of the District Court to deal with the latter is dealt with in the Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 . See also Kingswood Estates Ltd v Anderson [1963] 2 QB 169Â and Yahl v Bridgeport Customs Pty Ltd (SC(NSW), AllenÂ M, CLD 11290/84, 31 July 1984, unreported). A defence based upon equitable promissory estoppel is not an equitable ground of defence within the meaning of Law Reform (Law and Equity) Act 1972 s 6: Taylor Farms (Aust) Pty Ltd v A Calkos Pty Ltd [1999] NSWSC 186; BC9900793 at [72]–[84]Â per Kirby J (a case involving the jurisdiction of the Commercial Tribunal). Nor is it an “equitable claim or demand for recovery of money or damages” within the meaning of District Court Act s 134(1)(h) : Wilson v Interhealth Energies Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1137; BC200809569 at [10]–[12]Â per Adams J.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(h).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 sÂ 134(1)(h), sÂ 69.

The claim by a mortgagor against a mortgagee alleging a wrongful exercise of power of a sale is conventionally characterised as a proceeding in equity for an account (even though, it is arguably an open question in Australia whether there is available a common law claim in negligence against a mortgagee for, what may be described as a breach of the mortgagee's duty of care in the exercise of a power of sale: see Forsyth v Blundell (1973) 129 CLR 477; 1 ALR 68Â ; ANZ Banking Group Ltd v Bangadilly Pastoral Co Pty Ltd (1978) 139 CLR 195; 19 ALR 519Â ) see Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Hadfield (2001) 53 NSWLR 614; [2001] NSWCA 440; BC200107866 at [1], [40]–[48], [56]Â . The claim for such an account is clearly an "equitable claim … for the recovery of money". It may be also that it is an "equitable claim … for the recovery of … damages" within the terms of sÂ 134(1)(h) . Accordingly, where a judge permitted an amendment by a mortgagor to claim such an account the Court of Appeal refused to make an order under sÂ 69 Supreme Court Act 1970 prohibiting the District Court from further hearing proceedings: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Hadfield, above,at [1], [62]–[66], [67]Â . The amendment which introduced sÂ 134(1)(h) was not expressed to apply to proceedings pending in the court. As to the effect of an amendment made in proceedings which were instituted at a time when the court did not have such jurisdiction see Kirby Sanderson Motors Pty Ltd (2001) 54 NSWLR 135; BC200200586Â .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 sÂ 134(1)(h).

Section 134(1)(h) gives the court power to entertain a claim by a client that solicitors indemnify the client for the as yet unassessed costs payable to parties sued by the client in litigation which failed by reason of the solicitor's negligence: Kolavo v Pitsikas (t/as Comino and Pitsikas) [2003] NSWCA 59; BC200301408 at [10]–[12]Â , [69]–[70]. Semble a cross-claim for equitable damages from a breach of fiduciary duty said to arise from a partnership or joint-venture is not within the ambit of sÂ 134(1)(h) where the claim is in the context of proceedings for a dissolution of partnership: Tzovaras v Nufeno Pty Ltd [2003] FCA 1152; BC200306296 at [16], [38]Â . Very different principles may apply to common law actions in negligence, on the one hand, and claims for equitable compensation for breach of an equitable duty on the other with respect to causation, foreseeability and remoteness of damages: see for example, Beach Petroleum NL v Kennedy (1999) 48 NSWLR 1 at 89–93; 33 ACSR 1; [1999] NSWCA 408; BC9907249Â and Youyang Pty Ltd v Minter Ellison [2001] NSWCA 198; BC200106132 atÂ [16]Â . Courts at first instance must be careful to observe these differences and deal separately with the common law counts and the equitable counts before them, rather than endeavour to deal with the counts globally. If a person has a good remedy for damages in negligence, there is cause for equity to intervene by the remedy of equitable compensation only to the extent to which common law damages are clearly inadequate: Churchill v Connolly [2004] NSWCA 212; BC200404003 atÂ [56]–[59]Â per YoungÂ CJ inÂ Eq.

The Court shall have the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court, and may exercise all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court, in proceedings under DivisionÂ 4 of Part 3 of the Frustrated Contracts Act 1978, where the claim does not exceed the Court's jurisdictional limit in amount or value, as determined by the Court.
[sÂ 134A insrt Act 107 of 1978 sÂ 3 ; am Act 41 of 1982 Sch 1 ; Act 12 of 1991 sÂ 3 and Sch 2(2) ; Act 58 of 1997 sÂ 3 and Sch 1 ; Act No 28 of 2005 Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Frustrated Contracts Act 1978.
The Frustrated Contracts Act 1978 permits the court to make necessary adjustments to contractual rights where a contract is frustrated.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 134B] s 134B Jurisdiction in proceedings for review of contracts

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction in proceedings for review of contracts

p.text: The Court shall have the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court, and may exercise all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court, in proceedings in which relief under the Contracts Review Act 1980 is sought, where the amount or value of the consideration that has passed or would, if the contract were fully executed, pass from one contracting party to another does not exceed the amount for the time being specified in section 44(1)(a) , as determined by the Court.
Subsection (1) does not authorise the Court to exercise the powers conferred by section 10 of the Contracts Review Act 1980.
[sÂ 134B insrt Act 17 1980 sÂ 3]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 134B.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Contracts Review Act 1980 sÂ 7(1).
The Contracts Review Act 1980 came into force on 24 April 1980. Section 7(1) of that Act provides:

Where the Court finds a contract or a provision of a contract to have been unjust in the circumstances relating to the contract at the time it was made, the Court may, if it considers it just to do so, and for the purpose of avoiding as far as practicable an unjust consequence or result, do any one or more of the following:
it may decide to refuse to enforce any or all of the provisions of the contract,
it may make an order declaring the contract void, in whole or in part,
it may make an order varying, in whole or in part, any provision of the contract,
it may, in relation to a land instrument, make an order for or with respect to requiring the execution of an instrument that:
varies, or has the effect of varying, the provisions of the land instrument, or
terminates or otherwise affects, or has the effect of terminating or otherwise affecting, the operation or effect of the land instrument.”

By virtue of the provisions of sÂ 134B , the District Court has the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court in respect of the stated relief. This includes jurisdiction to grant declaratory relief: Adam v Sara [2010] NSWSC 530; BC201003425 atÂ [22]Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 135] s 135 Jurisdiction in proceedings under the Fair Trading Act 1987

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction in proceedings under the Fair Trading Act 1987

p.text: The Court has the same jurisdiction as the Supreme Court, and may exercise all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court, in any proceedings in which relief is sought under the Fair Trading Act 1987 and where the amount of the claim concerned does not exceed the amount for the time being specified in section 44(1)(a) .
[sÂ 135 insrt Act 34 of 1992 sÂ 3 and Sch 1]
[sÂ 136 rep Act 170 of 1984 sÂ 5 and Sch 3 now see Pt 2A r 1]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 137] s 137 Powers of the Court under this Subdivision

leg:heading.title: Powers of the Court under this Subdivision

p.text: In relation to proceedings under this Subdivision:

the Court and the Judges shall, in addition to the powers and authority otherwise conferred on it and them, have all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court and the Judges thereof in the like circumstances,
the appropriate officer of the Court shall, in addition to the duties otherwise imposed on the officer, discharge:
any duty which an officer of the Supreme Court would be required under the practice of the Supreme Court to discharge in the like circumstances, and
any duty imposed on the officer by the rules or by any order of the Court,

the practice and procedure of the Court shall, so far as practicable and subject to this Act and the rules, be the same as the practice and procedure of the Supreme Court applicable in the like circumstances, and

without affecting the generality of the foregoing provisions of this section, the powers, authority and duty conferred by paragraphs (a) and (b) , and the practice and procedure referred to in paragraph (c) , shall, subject to the rules, extend to the enforcement of any judgment or order of the Court in those proceedings.
[sÂ 137 am Act 32 of 1994 sÂ 3 and Sch 3]
Without affecting the generality of any other provision of this Act authorising the making of rules, the rules may make provision for or with respect to:
the procedure to be followed in respect of proceedings under this Subdivision, including the enforcement of any judgment or order of the Court in any such proceedings,
the costs of any such proceedings, and
any other matter necessary or convenient for giving effect to this Subdivision.
This section does not give power to make rules with respect to any matter relating to costs that is regulated by PartÂ 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004.
[subs (2) insrt Act 87 of 1993 sÂ 4 and Sch 6; am Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.4[3], effective 20 June 2006]
Division 7 applies to and in respect of proceedings under this Subdivision in the same way as if they were an action.
Legislation cited in [DCA s 139.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 DivisionÂ 7.

DivisionÂ 7 (containing ssÂ 125–131 of the District Court Act) deals generally with rights of appeal from judgments and orders relating to actions in the District Court. The present section applies those provisions to proceedings within the District Court’s miscellaneous jurisdiction under ssÂ 132–137 of the District Court Act. Consequently the “small appeals” limitation under DCA sÂ 127(2)(c) applies and no appeal lies, other than by leave, unless the amount, or the value of property, in issue meets the $100,000 threshold: Muldoon vÂ Church of England Children’s Homes Burwood [2011] NSWCA 46; BC201101466Â atÂ [18] per Campbell JA; Jensen vÂ Ray [2011] NSWCA 247 ; BC201106672Â atÂ [7] per Brereton J.
